name: Digital Linguistics (DLX)
description: Digital Linguistics (DLX) is the area of linguistics concerned with the digital representation and manipulation of linguistic data. Along with Patrick Hall and Eric Campbell at the University of California, Santa BarbaraJSON (JavaScript Object Notation), the canonical format for exchanging data on the web today. In addition, we are building a variety of browser-based tools designed to manage, edit, and otherwise manipulate data stored in this format. Because these tools all work in a web browser, they can be used on any platform, and take advantage of the rapidly-growing suite of web technologies. At the same time, these tools can be used offline, and can even store the linguist’s data locally rather than on a server.

name: Economics & Praxeology of Language
description: Following the Austrian school of economics, I approach the societal aspects of language from a praxeological perspective, i.e., understanding how language relates to human action, and how it serves as a means to the acting person’s ends. Such research is relevant to issues in language planning and policy, linguistic rights and intellectual property in language, and for studying power relations and socioeconomic trends as they relate to language.

name: Discourse & Prosody
description: One of the major insights of the linguistics of the past forty years is the fact that discourse has structure, and that structure is as systematic and complex as any other component of the grammar. A major focus of my work is to understand how it is that discourse gets its structure, and how this discourse-level structure in turn comes to shape other parts of the grammar. For example, my M.A. thesis, 'The cohesive function of prosody in Ékegusií (Kisii) narratives: A functional-typological approach', looks at the ways that prosody is used to lend cohesion to discourse, and my recent SSILA presentation, 'The extension of structure to discourse: Chitimacha participles in discourse and diachrony', shows that when morphemes take on discourse-level functions, they bring their previous morphological structure with them into discourse, thus adding new layers of discourse structure.

name: Typology & Linguistic Theory
description: My interests in language typology are largely theoretical, but also include the application of linguistic typology to the analysis of individual languages. My M.A. thesis aims to provide a functional definition of prosody for use in crosslinguistic research, and in a forthcoming paper I adopt a typological perspective to studying grammatical relations in Chitimacha. I am also especially interested in lexical categories and the nature of categories in language. My approach to language is largely functionalist – I see the ‘rules’ of language as a set of social conventions rather than algorithmic principles, and language itself as a complex adaptive system with numerous emergent properties. My interest in language typology ranges from the broadly theoretical (such as my dissertation on a typology of flexible word classes, or my review discussing Basic Linguistic Theory) to the applications of typology to specific languages (such as my description of semantic alignment in Chitimacha, or the discourse functions of prosody in Kisii). My approach to typology is largely functionalist, so that I view the ‘rules’ of language as a set of social conventions rather than algorithmic principles, and language itself as a complex adaptive system with numerous emergent properties.

name: Documentation & Revitalization
description:
Language documentation is the foundation on which my other theoretical work is built, and so I am deeply involved in the theorizing and practical implementation of language documentation. I serve as a student advisor to <dfn><abbr title='Institute on Collaborative Language Documentation'>CoLang</abbr></dfn> (the Institute on Collaborative Language Documentation), and through my work at Rosetta Stone’s Endangered Language Program, I helped to create language-learning software for the Iñupiaq, Inuttitut, Mohawk, Navajo, and Chitimacha languages. These projects involved many hours of long-distance and in-person elicitation, followed by an intense process of designing software to teach grammar and vocabulary. Since then I have continued to work with the Chitimacha tribe on a grammar and dictionary of the language, based on documentary materials compiled by Morris Swadesh in the 1930’s.
I also work with the <dfn>Ékegusií Encyclopedia Project</dfn> (<abbr title='Ekegusii Encyclopedia Project'>EEP</abbr>) to document and revitalize the Ékegusií (Kisii) language of western Kenya. In the summer of 2014 I spent two months in Kisii Town recording traditional narratives, songs, and expository texts in the language, and these constituted the data for my M.A. thesis on the cohesive function of prosody in Ékegusií. I also give talks on topics relating to language endangerment and strategies for revitalization, and I frequently review books relating to language endangerment and revitalization.
Finally, through my work on Digital Linguistics, I aim to provide some of the practical tools that will enable linguists to do better documentation in an easier way.

Independent Research Project: <cite>Language change & variation in Mombasa: Recent trends in Kimvita Swahili</cite>

description: Two semesters researching language shift in the Kimvita (Mombasa dialect of Swahili. Worked primarily with youth speakers collecting recorded texts for analysis.
One-year, graduate-level field methods class working with a speaker of Tlahuapa Mixtec.

Daily elicitation with speakers of Navajo and Iñupiaq for the purpose of creating Rosetta Stone language software. Included both long-distance elicitation and numerous on-site visits, generally for two weeks at a time.
Ongoing preparation of a Chitimacha dictionary, text collection, and grammar from archival sources. Completed Rosetta Stone language-learning software in 2010.
Two weeks of elicitation with a native speaker of the Point Hope dialect of Iñupiaq.
Two months of fieldwork in western Kenya, recording conversation as well as traditional songs and folktales in Ékegusií.
An undergraduate-level descriptive linguistics / field methods course with a native speaker of Turkish.
